title: Monday, 11th June, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:05am

Hello! Welcome to Monday, hi, good morning.

Grouchmonkey Morning all
BE11:05am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's etc.

Manxish Morning each
Excel Developer Recession Live!
ActiveValue1 Morning
Soundbuy Morning
OnYourRight Morning all
Grouchmonkey OK, I admit it. I've got some XLMedia. Is it really as bad as it looks?
BE11:05am

Quite a busy weekend for news, though much of it was completely nonsensical.

Excel Developer Recession. Get ahead of the herd, sell stocks.
Grouchmonkey Actually, let's talk about Inmarsat instead.
Shrink Morning
11:07 am
BE11:07am

(If someone can break down the characters in the current Sunday Times-Observer fight into a flowchart, or maybe some kind of anime comic series, I for one would much appreciate it.)

BE11:07am

Meanwhile, across the pond, we have this: https://www.politi...ling-system-635164

Alchemy30 Morning, Anyone else frustrated with the timing of ISAT's RNSI missed it by milliseconds
Shrink Did BE just say anime?
BE11:08am

About Trump’s 'odd and enduring habit of ripping up papers when he’s done with them — what some people described as his unofficial “filing system.”'

11:08 am
BE11:08am

It's an extraordinary story all the way to the bottom.

Peace and Love America's Trump is a bottomless pit of absurdity
BE11:09am

Anyway, that'll do for a preamble. We can cut to the actually revevant to our interests news of the day.

undefined
Swedish Chef Didnt Dennis Healy write ‘bollocks’ on papers he didn’t agree with?
11:10 am
BE11:10am

@Alchemy30: why didn't you just buy it when we flagged up the rumour during Friday's session? Honestly, how much spoon feeding do you need?

Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 531.20, up 57.3 (+12.09%), High: 540.00, Low: 494.00, Volume: 9.42m
Deep Breath everyone... @Peas and Love - but nevertheless he is actually getting progress made in some areas that have seen none for 50 years.
Alchemy30 A RAW tag might have been nice :-)
BE11:10am

........... so, bang on Friday's close, we get confirmation that Inmarsat received an offer from Echostar.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Which is of course an outcome we've been talking about in general terms for about five years, on and off.

BE11:11am

And in specific terms for about a month.

BE11:12am

No price, only "very significantly undervalued"

11:12 am
BE11:12am

And as we wrote in Friday's hastily cobbled together news story .....

BE11:12am

Inmarsat has long been seen by analysts as vulnerable to a bid from a regional satellite operator looking to stitch together spectrum licences, particularly as earnings deteriorated. In recent years, the decline in its share price has also knocked it out of the FTSE 100 large-cap index and into the FTSE 250 index for mid-sized groups.

The group, which takes the majority of revenue from its shipping business, also rents its spectrum to Ligado Networks, a US hybrid network that plans to launch in competition with EchoStar and Dish Network, Mr Ergen’s sister company.

BE11:13am

https://www.ft.com...-b6eb-4acfcfb08c11

nichoman will ISAT happens ? seems like one of those deals where board feel they can't sell at such a discount to where share price was XX months ago but paying that price would be too high a premium for acquirer
Soundbuy Like my RAW truly RAW..........
11:13 am
BE11:13am

That's the important bit, and arguably the most interesting bit of the tale.

Soundbuy ......dragged up from the depths of some sleazy bar in Mayfair.....
BE11:14am

Here's the link to that Ligado filing, which again we flagged up last week: https://ecfsapi.fc...53120688074/Ligado License Modification Cover Letter and Amendment (5-31-2018).pdf

BE11:15am

Gah. Try this one: https://bit.ly/2kC9S3L (PDF)

11:15 am
BE11:15am

99% reduction in power usage, they claim. And if Ligado gets off the ground it'd be very bad for Dish.

BE11:15am

As in Charlie Ergen’s sister company.

hedgehog BCA ?
BE11:16am

So you probably have to see all this as an opportunity for Mr Ergen to throw sand into the wheels of a competitor.

Timmmmmmmyyyyyy Hi there, please any view as to why EchoStar hasn't put out a statement (yet)? Very unusual. Thanks
11:16 am
BE11:16am

I'll cut to RBC's Wilton Fry, who's been excellent on this all the way through.

BE11:17am

Spectrum (£10/share): We estimate Inmarsat's spectrum is worth c.£10 per share, split European S-band (£3.25), US L-band (£5.00), Global L- band (£1.55). Spectrum is extremely important to Echostar and its sister company DISH (both controlled by Charlie Ergen). S-band: Echostar owns the other S-band licence and is planning to use it for mobile broadband spectrum. Owning Inmarsat would allow Echostar to have the same frequencies in Europe that DISH owns in the US. The FCC has converted these to mobile usage (AWS-4) and DISH has approval from 3GPP for Band 66 (S-band) to be used for mobile broadband in Europe and the US. US L-band: DISH attempted to buy SkyTerra (now Ligado) in 2012. Owning Inmarsat would allow Echostar to use Inmarsat's spectrum and gain control of some of Ligado's own spectrum if Ligado were to go bankrupt. Worldwide L-band: The same L-band can be used worldwide for IoT usage (especially interesting to SoftBank)

BE11:17am

That's in addition to $3.7bn of potential synergies.

Mouselet Good morning assorted and miscellaneous people
Grouchmonkey £300 doesn't buy you much at Mayfair prices, I wouldn't have thought?
11:18 am
BE11:18am

(@Swedish Chef: I'll have to delete any comments on that subject, apologies in advance.)

Mouselet I note that the original comment has been zogged
Upaswellasdown fair enough, sorry.
Soundbuy @Swedish Chef - you've been zapped.......or dementia's setting in........
BE11:19am

(ROTR: I'm deleting any comments on that subject, apologies in advance.)

BE11:19am

(Trust me here, I'm only following orders.)

Swedish Chef @mouse same story in mail,Guardian etc. More in the Sun on WPP than this journal
11:20 am
BE11:20am

So, counterbidders .......

BE11:20am

Counter Bidders: (1) ViaSat: Hughes (Echostar) is ViaSat's arch rival and the same logic that applies to Echostar also applies to ViaSat. Although ViaSat's balance sheet is stretched, by using its highly rated equity it could afford to buy Inmarsat, reduce leverage and neutralise Echostar simultaneously. (See our separate note on ViaSat.) (2) SES/Eutelsat: Both operators are expanding fast into Mobility as their core Video business shrinks, however both struggle with leverage and low relative rating. (3) Mobile operators: Inmarsat's worldwide L-band (IoT opportunity), S-band in Europe, and L-band could make Inmarsat attractive to many large mobile operators. (4) Private Equity: PE has a long history in the sector. We estimate the IRR of a LBO/MBO at 16-17% using a 750p offer excluding what Inmarsat could do with the spectrum in private hands.

Upaswellasdown though I think the value of popbitch as newsource is misunderstood. They had an excellent series on National Enquirer last year
BE11:21am

Oh, and just as a kicker.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

We believe Inmarsat is on the verge of signing a deal to wholesale its 4th GX satellite for Chinese use. We think this is worth c. $100m/year or c.£1/share post-tax.

BE11:21am

RBC are buyers up to 850p.

Mouselet Grr, the Italians ...
Pseudonym @BE Sorry, what subject?
BE11:21am

Jefferies fancies it even more.

Mouselet I am moderately confused as to why Boeing and Hughes don't build and operate their own satellites rather than adding one and a half layers of people-in-the-middle
11:21 am
BE11:22am

The EchoStar bid for Inmarsat is not about sector consolidation. It's about spectrum. We think Dish is looking for negotiating leverage following news that Ligado could be on the cusp of finally getting its license modification reinstated. If we're wrong, Inmarsat shareholders could hold out for as much as £11 per share. If we're right, they should be pushing for something even higher. This is only the beginning, in our view.

Mouselet I guess building satellites for someone else for money has a well-defined profit margin
Pharma @Swedish, glad your comment with the company name got through. I was getting very confused about what subject it was I wasn't supposed to comment on.
BE11:22am

Ergen, "must feel fortuitous that the Ligado risk coincided with a massive de-rating in his single best tool of negotiating leverage (namely, Inmarsat, as critical supplier to Ligado)," they say.

#REF! Understandable BE. Will be interesting to see if the company now responds to the articles
BE11:23am

So, hold out for a gigantic offer, they say.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

he EchoStar share price has come down materially of late meaning the maximum offer price for Inmarsat that still allows for year 3 FCF per share accretion is £11. Grounds enough for Inmarsat to negotiate hard. Quantifying the importance to EchoStar / Dish of negotiating leverage around its mid-band spectrum is difficult, but if we're right in our assessment, then Inmarsat has grounds to secure an offer even higher.

Mouselet Ligado is an interesting political debate: whether in the Trump regime the American FCC gets to outvote the DOD
Mouselet (why on Earth anyone ever thought that a thing that would break GPS might conceivably get through still amazes me)
VV75 any inkling of the price of the first, declined, offer?
Mouselet but being amazed may be my normal state. I did like the way Fox News described Trump/KJU as 'meeting between the two dictators'
BE11:24am

Now, keep in mind that Inmarsat has a 6.9% short out there.

Alchemy30 Where's the bear case
BE11:24am

Most of which is AQR Capital Management .....

Pseudonym KJU is a king rather than just a dictator, appointed by virtue of birthright.
Soundbuy Inmarsat and Ocado - shorters having a rough old ride of late.........
VV75 isat's rns said very significantlyy undervalued, but that's what all companies say
Pharma Does the "spectrum is worth £10" comment (when the shares sell for £5) essentially mean that using it for satellites is an economically very silly idea, or is it just wishful thinking?
11:26 am
BE11:26am

The bear case being, of course, that it makes most of its cash from shipping and Ligado revenue might disappear after this year and there's a load of sunk costs going into the aerospace stuff with no clear payback ......

Mouselet It is possible to use the same spectrum for mobile phones in the US and satellite wifi in the mid-Pacific, I think
BE11:26am

........ and you've also got the loss of a monopoly over emergency shipping contacts the other week.

Pharma @Mouselet, but the analyst comment broke the value down by region, so I think that is taken account of.
A. M. @Pseudonym: but has he had some strange watery woman throw a sword at him?
BE11:27am

With the shares up 33% in a fortnight, it looks pretty risky up here. That's a point Numis makes.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

We do not advise shorting ISAT's stock but, unless the company's value prospects are better detailed than they have been hitherto, we think shareholders should reduce holdings if the share price climbs materially higher. This is because (i) we believe Echostar will not follow through, (ii) we doubt ISAT shareholders will get clarity over the likelihood and NPV of future Ligado cash soon enough, and (iii) we believe the threat from Iridium to ISAT's NPV will keep growing at pace. We made numerous small changes to our ISAT forecasts post 1Q FY18 results, so our Target Price inches back from 450p to 430p per share.

Excel Developer watery bint
BE11:28am

You get the idea.

undefined
11:29 am
BE11:29am

In terms of the day's other bid story .....

BCA Marketplace PLC (BCA:LSE): Last: 232.00, up 21 (+9.95%), High: 239.50, Low: 213.50, Volume: 14.06m
BE11:29am

Odd one.

Pseudonym I'm not sure that sword flinging watery women are a requirement for absolute monarchies, but I'm sure he could arrange it..
Alchemy30 BCA - Another recently called short
Electric Dragon Supreme executive power derives from a mandate from the masses, not from some farcical aquatic ceremony!
11:30 am
BE11:30am

Kleinman says mid Saturday that Apax Partners "is among a pack of private equity firms circling BCA"

A. M. @Pseudonym: well, we've had a supreme leader finding an ancient vase while taking a dip, so a sword ought to be easy.
BE11:31am

Now, I don't want to let daylight into magic here, but when a report says "a pack of private equity firms" there are only really two possibilities .....

Pseudonym NK must have a synchronised swimming team, the more I think about this the better I think they could do it.
Pseudonym No-one does pageantry as well as NK.
BE11:32am

... one is that lots of people familiar with all of those private equity firms have contacted the journalist to confirm that their tip of interest is right, albeit without identifying which specific private equity firm they're familiar with.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

The other is that there's a person familiar with the target, not the potential bidders.

A. M. (was that one of the reasons for the KJU/DT meeting, then? Exchange of parade ideas?)
BE11:33am

Which makes today's statement interesting. Turns out Apax bid 200p a month ago and nothing's happened since.

Soundbuy Talktalk has put on 5% since the session started - Tosca have RNSed they've increased their stake a tad.......
BE11:34am

Though Apax is still interested, sort of.

Pharma #Sword aren't you getting confused here? According to Disney, he got the sword from a stone. Much easier to arrange.
11:34 am
BE11:34am

Apax confirms that it is in the early stages of considering an offer for BCA to be made by a new entity controlled by funds advised by Apax (“Apax Funds”). This announcement does not amount to a firm intention to make an offer and accordingly there can be no certainty that an offer will made.

In accordance with Rule 2.6(a) of the Code, Apax is required, by not later than 5.00 p.m. on 8 July 2018, to either announce a firm intention that the Apax Funds will make an offer for BCA in accordance with Rule 2.7 of the Code or announce that it does not, and that the Apax Funds do not, intend to make an offer, in which case the announcement will be treated as a statement to which Rule 2.8 of the Code applies. This deadline can be extended with the consent of the Panel in accordance with Rule 2.6(c) of the Code.

BE11:35am

Now .... you'll remember from earlier in the year that BCA was attracting increasing interest from short sellers.

Delta1_ETF BOOHOO & Paris Hilton collection to be launched. BOOHOO results out tomorrow :)
BE11:35am

Having a bid story out there probably does the company no harm.

Pharma He could also go the Alexander the Great route, and cleave a huge knot. Perhaps with an AA gun.
Swedish Chef @psedo Agreed. Was in Pyongyang for this (If this link doesn’t get zapped) https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=UPThbdSFg8M
11:35 am
BE11:36am

But anyway ..... Despite being FTSE 250 no one covers BCA and it barely trades.

BE11:36am

Closest thing I have to comment this morning is from Liberum.

BE11:36am

BCA owns and operates Europe’s largest automotive exchange network, providing a range of vehicle management services to OEMs, leasing companies and dealerships. The company's share price has recovered by 41% since mid-March following a period of volatile performance in Q1 2017. The Q1 share price decline may have been driven by market concerns regarding new car sales in the UK. BCA has, however, been gaining share in the volume of used vehicles processed through its infrastructure and is also expected to benefit from providing services to OEMs and leasing companies to maximise residual values in this environment. Given BCA's last closing price of 211p, we would expect any potential bid will need to be significantly higher than 200p in order to be successful. Marwyn currently trades on a -31.7% discount to our live NAV estimate.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

37% of Marwyn's NAV, says Liberum. Which leads me to question why anyone would bother investing in Marwyn.

undefined
Flaneur Poundland gone under says Rutters. Anyone here affected? :)
urgeview BE...any chance of posting the volumes for the ftse index review on Friday if you have them ? TIA.
Soundbuy Marwyn - their Ent One was quite large before selling up IIRC............
BE11:38am

On TalkTalk, there's a Deutsche Bank buy note around but I've not dug it out yet.

11:38 am
Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 113.80, up 5.7 (+5.27%), High: 114.40, Low: 108.70, Volume: 741.40k
PeterC So a month ago Apax was talking about 200p., a tiny 5% premium to the price at the time(190ish). Are they go to raise by 18-20% or so? ..240 high today and still well up

Flaneur Yeah...oops sorry.
11:41 am
BE11:41am

Last heard out theories around Virgin Media interest at the end of last month, which appeared to have no basis in truth.

Mouselet Are there plans for FTTP build-out actually to happen?
BE11:42am

Possibly just random noise around a duct sharing agreement.

jaws MVI hold 25.6 % of ZEG too.
undefined
11:42 am
BE11:42am

Elsewhere in sellside, there's Ocado. Because there's always Ocado.

FATDAZ @BE what about competition issues if Virgin were to bid ? Find it hard to imagine a domestic buyer could avoid an inquiry
Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 1,052, up 52.6 (+5.26%), High: 1,083, Low: 1,009, Volume: 3.18m
BE11:44am

Goldman upgrades to buy, having spent approximately 15 seconds on a neutral recommendation.

Flaneur Excessive rents again cited as a problem in retail probs. Mr Carney has pushed market valuations too high and is now impacting the real world. Oh dear. Shame nobody saw that coming....
11:44 am
BE11:44am

BE11:45am

There's also a Bernstein upgrade, which is a better read, but let's get the house broker out of the way first.

Mouselet Does Amazon own its distribution facilities outright?
BE11:45am

Ocado’s announced partnership with Kroger was transformational in
our opinion, both in the number of distribution centres Kroger is
looking to start building (a commitment to 20 CFCs vs 1 CFC in each
of Ocado’s three previous OSP deals), and in the validation of
Ocado’s Smart Platform (OSP) as an online grocery solution with a
global addressable market. Though the stock price moved materially
to reflect this, our analysis at a local market level points to a US
opportunity more than double Kroger’s initial commitment, with the
economics to Kroger clear on our calculations. Analysis of the top
50 food retailers globally points to an addressable grocery revenue
pool (not bound by existing exclusivity contracts) of over £250bn, an
OSP opportunity equivalent to over 2x Kroger-sized deals. Finally,
our updated work on Ocado’s core business points to a UK retail
business worth c.700p, with further potential upside from further
automation of Ocado’s CFCs. With c.21% upside to our new 1,160p
price target, we upgrade back to Buy from Neutral.

FATDAZ @mouselett do you mean globally or locally ?
Soundbuy Guessed that Amazon Logistics was well......Amazon Logistics
Mouselet I suspect I mean globally
11:46 am
BE11:46am

And here's Bruno at Bernstein, with the very big numbers.

BE11:46am

We had a good handle on who would partner but we had scale & speed all wrong. Instead of buying a marginal CFC (=picking centre), KR started with the end in mind: how many CFCs does it take for proper ecom? Instead of our 1-4 CFC forecast, the deal was for 20 in first 3 yrs.

Consumers want grocery ecom. But shabby execution stops it from breaking through in many countries. An incumbent with decent execution creates the market and takes disproportionate share. This is what happened in the UK, France & Netherlands. Ocado seems the only valid partner to help incumbents in markets without grocery ecom to create and take the market.

Delta1_ETF Will there only be Coffee Shops and Charity shops left on the high street? 99% of the time i do things from mobile (shopping, banking, investments etc)
Mouselet I can't imagine they want to be beholden to landlords (I would sort of expect them not to want to be beholden to freeholders)
Mouselet Clothes shopping is still slightly better when you can try them on
BE11:48am

These deals are not for single CFCs: they are for necessary infrastructure to take major share in a developed ecommerce segment -- 5% of total grocery. If that happens (we think it will), the existing deals already provide Ocado access to a $162bn grocery ecom market {2025}. We expect more countries to join {potentially Germany, Japan, Australia, Spain, Italy, Switzerland, …}. Probability-weighting those takes us to a $205bn grocery ecommerce market {2025}. For Ocado partners to take their market share (15%-35%) requires 98 CFCs. Ocado has 25 signed already, and 73 more to come from existing and new partners.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

By 2023, current deals alone get them to £220m EBITDA, growing at 60-80%, warranting a 50X EV/EBITDA, or £12.5bn EV. Taking off debt, discounting, etc. gets us to £9.5bn EV.

Mouselet Twitter was suggesting that something of the order of 15% of 50+ households own a second house
Mouselet I am not sure I can see any of this ending well
BE11:48am

Bernstein also flags the idea -- new to me, but totally logical -- that Ocado should sell its UK business back to Waitrose.

Lefevre I can see how these deals are good for Ocado, will partners like Kroger really be able to make money from them?
Grouchmonkey @mouselet - how many of those are occupied by their offspring?
BE11:49am

Target £13.

Tom Dalgleish Who was it said Ocado is at limit with existing contracts?
11:49 am
undefined
Excel Developer @mouselet: the greedy silver haired ones
Mouselet I would have thought those were usually structured in such a way that the offspring owned the house
Mouselet if only to avoid iht
Grouchmonkey You would think so but some oldies find it hard to let go.....
BE11:50am

(@Tom: Morgan Stanley did that work, I think.)

BE11:52am

..... and with that, I'm not sure there's anything else.

Tom Dalgleish Is Ocado in some ways still experimental?
#REF! Redcentric trading warning Friday afternoon?
Grouchmonkey xlmedia?
chad_john UKOG!
#REF! If you are looking for something to mention, I know its small (AIM is where all the..... fun is)
11:54 am
BE11:54am

Oh, right, yes. There are some smallcap things.

FATDAZ @Tom D yes I think you can say that UK seems to have been testbed for wider ambitions
Pharma Wonder how much of the 15% related to couples meeting in middle age, when both have a house. Some will also be reluctant landlords, who needed to move for work but couldn't sell.
#REF! or yes or XLmedia, programmatic advertising is tough right now
BE11:54am

Including Redcentric's Friday afternoon warning.

BE11:55am

Profit phasing from its Yorkshire & Humber contract takes ebitda 10% below previous guidance.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

As well as cancellations of public sector hosting
contracts

BE11:56am

General weakness in new business sales

BE11:56am

And upfront costs for Yorkshire & Humber, which now looks to be lossmaking in FY19.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

Quick line from Numis.

BE11:57am

We lower our FY19 EBITDA forecast by 13%, and although EBITDA forecast reductions are lower in subsequent years, we still make meaningful cuts (FY20 & 21 EPS down c.10%). Broadly in line with our longer-term forecast cuts we lower our target price to 108p from 120p and our recommendation to Add from Buy

Lefevre @Fatdaz, agree - Uk customers would appear to have been the white mice in the lab for Ocado!
BE11:57am

Looking beyond FY19, management is clearly
very confident about the path of profits from this contract, and we think their expectation for profits once mature have risen since the contract was announced. The group is bidding for a number of similar albeit smaller contracts, with one already secured.

11:58 am
undefined
BE11:58am

And, yes okay, XLMedia.

XLMedia PLC (XLM:LSE): Last: 126.75, down 44.25 (-25.88%), High: 132.00, Low: 119.00, Volume: 10.91m
jaws Any thing in BATM please ? BVC
11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Not sure we've covered it since the float: https://ftalphavil...alcon&desktop=true

Tom Dalgleish The Kroger reaction was a blip
BE12:00pm

Anyway, it's one of those exciting digital ad companies that doesn't grow revenue year on year.

BE12:01pm

Here's Berenberg to summarise.

Flaneur Accidentally joined Amazon prime with my last purchase. It seems to be a combination of a delivery service, a tv channel, a bookshop and cloud storeage. Only things missing are a takeaway and a recommend-a-handyman app. Very random. Will be cancelling before months trial ends.
12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

XLMedia (XLM) has released a trading statement this morning which indicates that its 2018 results will now be marginally lower than those in 2017A. This is largely the result of a number of regulatory oneoffs. While in the long run these favour XLM, they have created a negative short-term impact. Reflecting these, we reduce our estimates by c12%. With the business model still solid, the company accelerating its efforts in the US and the company in evaluation stages for a number of deals, we would view a pullback in the shares as an entry point for longer-term investors. XLM shares trade on c12.9x cash-adjusted P/E (16.5x normalised) with a c6% FCF yield. We remain buyers but move our one-year price target to 225p.

BE12:01pm

Hm.

BE12:02pm

A number of changes in the past six months have
created some short-term pressures for XLM. 1) New consumer protection rights have forced operators to adapt their guidelines on how terms and conditions (T&Cs) are advertised to customers. This has created one-off delays to some affiliate advertising practices. 2) Interim changes to XLM’s payment model (ie a switch by some operators to revenue share from cost per acquisition) create lower short-term revenues but greater opportunity in the long run. 3) XLM has selectively pruned some low-margin media revenue streams in an effort to refocus on higher-margin pushing work. The company is comfortable with a return to growth in 2019E.

chad_john rev share on marketing spend? At last!
chad_john a proper way to hold agencies to account?
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

(@Flaneur: it interests me that, if you enter "cancel" into a Google Calendar event its first autocomplete suggestion is "Cancel Amazon Prime". )

Tom Dalgleish @Flan, good luck with the unsubscription maze a la WSJ
Mouselet It's not that bad, you do not for example need to send them a physical letter
Tom Dalgleish Is WSJ a swear word?
Excel Developer My build soc stopped the stealth Amazon Prime signup.
BE12:04pm

And have Panmure as well, since we're here.

Excel Developer (Nationwide Build Soc).
Pharma @Flan, when I cancelled Prime at the last moment, I got an extra month for free to try to persuade me to stay (took the 2nd month, then left)
BE12:05pm

12:05 pm
undefined
BE12:05pm

Eh?

Soundbuy AA - in this day and age you need to call to stop auto-renewal...............zzzzzzz
BE12:05pm

*CANACCORD GENUITY REPORTS PROPOSED MERGER WITH SPARK POWER CORP

Pharma @BE, I suspect that is a Google engineers idea of humour, rather than the result of machine-learning autocomplete.
12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

Canaccord the IB?

BE12:06pm

Oh .... https://www.newswi...orp-685110361.html

Mr Diamond no its a SPAC
BE12:06pm

TORONTO, June 11, 2018 CNW - Canaccord Genuity Acquisition Corp. (TSX: CGAC.UN, CGAC.WT) ("CGAC") today announced its proposed merger (the "Merger") with Spark Power Corp. ("Spark Power"). The Merger will constitute CGAC's qualifying acquisition.

Spark Power is a leading independent electrical power services and solutions company serving more than 4,500 industrial, commercial, institutional, renewable and agricultural customers, as well as utility markets including municipalities, universities, schools and hospitals across North America. In addition, Spark Power maintains and operates over 2,000 solar and wind energy assets and has over 600 megawatts of renewable power under management, managing two of the largest renewable energy co-ops in Canada.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

That makes more sense, in a way the Bloomberg flash really didn't.

undefined
BE12:08pm

Okay, we're done. Ta for sticking around.

12:08 pm
BE12:08pm

And thanks for behaving yourself in the comments.

Soundbuy Cheers.........
Grouchmonkey Thanks for XLM and all - bye
BE12:08pm

See you tomorrow. Afternoon all.

Alchemy30 thanks
Excel Developer bye
FATDAZ bye
Swedish Chef Thanks BE.
